text:
Asparagus is a green, white, or purple spike
of a vegetable that heralds spring, goes well

with eggs...and makes your pee smell really
weird.
Or, maybe it doesn't.

About 4 out of 10 of people don’t seem to
experience stinky asparagus pee, either because

they don’t make it, or they can't smell
it—or both.

Great minds have pondered this smelly mystery
since at least 1731, when a Scottish physician

noticed that eating asparagus gave urine a
definite funk.

But, nearly 300 years later, we still don’t
totally understand this stink partly because

it isn't a particularly high-priority research
area, and partly because despite centuries

of scientific and technological progress,
the gold standard for this research field
still seems to involve sniffing pee.

Pee sniffing has helped scientists figure
out the basics.

In a 2010 study, researchers collected pee
from people both after they ate asparagus,

and after they ate bread, then invited the
urinators back to sniff everyone’s creations.

Some people declined to return, perhaps because
of what the researchers called an “unanticipated
aversion to urine."

Of the participants that did agree to sniff,
a few couldn’t distinguish the samples of

asparagus-pee from their bread-pee counterparts—which
suggests that some people just can’t smell
asparagus funk.

We don’t know exactly why yet, but variation
in a set of olfactory receptor genes may be

what separates the asparagus-pee smellers
from the non-smellers.

What’s more, a few people in this study
produced asparagus and bread pee samples that

were indistinguishable to everyone, suggesting
some people don’t make stinky asparagus
pee.

But here’s where pee sniffing falls short,
because it’s also possible that something

even stinkier in those samples masked the
asparagus odor.

To figure out what’s causing the stink,
researchers turned to scientific sniffing,

and found five sulfur-containing compounds
that were up to thousands of times more abundant

in the air above the stinky pee than above
the non-stinky pee.

These may be produced when an asparagus-specific
molecule called "asparagussic" acid, or is
it "asparagoosic"?

"asparageezic"?. anyway, when this acid breaks
down in the body.

But that doesn’t explain why some people
get stinky pee, and others don’t; perhaps

stinky pee-ers — or their gut microbes — metabolize
that molecule differently than their less
funky counterparts.

Maybe in the next 300 years, scientists will
solve this Pee-Culiar mystery.

But until then, there’s lots of asparagus
to be eaten, and pee to be sniffed.
It’s for science, people.
Hi, this is Kate from MinuteEarth!

If you’re as curious about this subject
as we are, stay tuned to help us do a little
research of our own.

But first, we want to give a big thanks to

Thanks - your pee-ticipation could help solve
the mystery!
